bLTDUx-w6.memHandModelNotes:
Open Water and accept all MU's within buffer.  Restrict freshwater to larger lakes only. Amy Silvano 05sept05

Flowing water will not show up in NHD as reservoirs. This species is a deep water diving duck. I changed this model to have flowing and standing water buffers as unlimited interior distance (9999). No MUs were selected, so I selected only water MUs. I also added a minimum patch size of 10 ha to account for "large freshwater lakes" as per Common Goldeneye wintering model. Hand model to include only the deepest parts of water features by selecting a minimum interior buffer distance of 500m., i.e. interior buffers should start 500m from shore and go unlimited into water features. MJR 16Aug07 and 12 March 2008.

references.A75ALI01NAUS: Alison, R.M. 1975. Breeding biology and behavior of the old-squaw (CLANGULA HYEMALIS). Amer. Ornith. Union, Monog. No. 18. 52 pp.
references.B83AOU01USGP: American Ornithologists' Union (AOU). 1983. Check-list of North American Birds, 6th edition. Allen Press, Inc., Lawrence, Kansas. 877 pp.
references.B88MAD01NAUS: Madge, S., and H. Burn. 1988. Waterfowl:an identification guide to the ducks, geese and swans of the world. Houghton Mifflin Co., Boston. 298 pp.
references.B77COG01NAUS: Cogswell, H.L. 1977. Water birds of California. Univ. California Press, Berkeley. 399 pp.
references.B89JOH01NAUS: Johnson, S.R., and D.R. Herter. 1989. The birds of the Beaufort Sea. BP Exploration (Alaska) Inc., Anchorage, Alaska. 372 pp.
references.B88ROO01NAUS: Root, T. 1988. Atlas of wintering North American birds:An analysis of Christmas Bird Count data. University of Chicago Press. 336 pp.
references.U94KEH01NAUS: Kehoe, P., compiler and editor. 1994. Status and information needs of sea ducks in the Atlantic Flyway. Prepared by the Ad Hoc Sea Duck Committee. 71+ pp.
references.B76BEL01NAUS: Bellrose, F.C. 1976. Ducks, geese and swans of North America. Stackpole Books, Harrisburg, Pa.
references.B80TER01NAUS: Terres, J.K. 1980. The Audubon Society encyclopedia of North American birds. Alfred A. Knopf, New York.
references.B78HAR01NAUS: Harrison, C. 1978. A field guide to the nests, eggs and nestlings of North American birds. Collins, Cleveland, Ohio.
references.B02ROB01SEGP: Robertson, G.J. and J.-P. L. Savard. 2002. Long-tailed duck (Clangula hyemalis).  In The Birds of North America, No. 651 (A. Poole and F. Gill, eds.). The Birds of North America, Inc., Philadelphia, PA.

habitat_description:
The Long-tailed Duck (Clangula hyemalis) winters in waters of the Mid-atlantic, Northeastern, Great Lakes, and Northwestern U.S.  It typically inhabits coastal marine waters and large inland freshwater lakes but can also be found a great distance offshore (>10 Km) (Natureserve, Andrews and Righter 1992, Robertson and Savard 2002).  It prefers waters along rocky headlands in New Hampshire but is also found near sand shores and rocky ledges.  In northwestern Washington State, it prefers to use protected bays with sandy or cobble bottoms, steep slopes, and shorelines with gradual shelves (Robertson and Savard 2002).  Although uncommon, habitat may also include big rivers with low gradient (Natureserve). 
N. Tarr, 22July2011.
